text: this gold bowtie belongs to a crossover
small enough to park in a suburban okay
that's a stretch but tracks yes with an
axe is 11 inches shorter than a Toyota
rav4 on Tom Volk with driven for the New
York Times you'll be seeing more
subcompact crossover soon including Jeep
renegade Mazda cx-3 and Honda HRV Trax
is new to the US market but if you have
traveled to Canada or Mexico in the last
year and a half or so you may have
already seen this vehicle why have we
been denied so long well it's possible
General Motors simply didn't have the
capacity for production or it could be
Buicks fault
encore shares its architecture with
tracks a smash hit attracting younger
buyers Buick can't make enough of them
more profitable as a premium product
it's smart business to launch the Chevy
version now that production is ramped up
in Mexico and Korea the same 1.4 liter
turbo 4-cylinder powers tracks making
138 horsepower
and 148 pound-feet of torque
the six-speed Automatic has manual
shifting here not here this one is front
drive 1,500 bucks sends power to all
four tires handy in conditions like this
for an attraction track saunters to 60
in about nine and a half seconds slower
than the tree frog that is Nissan Juke
the Chevy's ample low-end torque is good
for city skirmishes so is the diminutive
size one thing this rig inherited from
Buick it's very quiet when cruising
though put your foot into it and you
will hear the engine especially on steep
roads and highway merging at least the
engine is refined epa rated fuel economy
is about the same as the larger honda
crv Trax is a very small crossover but
it feels solid not cheap and tinny
steering is well weighted ride quality
is dialed towards comfort but not mushy
overall driving dynamics are well sorted
for a tall short crossover handling fans
will gravitate towards Subaru and
present Chevy's twin cockpit look is
found inside materials look soft they
are not if hamsters go for Kia Soul
squirrels will choose tracks there's
plenty of places to stash things away
no covered center storage though premium
LTZ models have comfortable heated
leatherette seats no CD player for the
punchy bose system no auto climate
control either install the bring go app
on your smart phone and it puts
navigation on this 7-inch screen
lots of glass gives the cozy cabin a
roomier feel visibility is great except
out the back be glad for this foot leg
knee and Headroom are generous back here
but I have the feeling of sitting on the
seats not in them there are even more
cubbies back here and an outlet to
charge computers not just phones Trax
has a built-in 4G LTE hotspot there are
belts for three best keep it to two back
here time for the trunk test remember
Trax is not a very big vehicle
four packs ties with Kia Soul there are
even more storage slots back here and
comforting to know it carries one of
these during the light off-roading Trax
is capable of this rig will most likely
be bought by singles couples so I
brought 16 packs out believing if I drop
the rear seats it would easily fill the
space there's actually room for one or
two more oh and this folds forward for
long stuff with ten standard airbags
this cute crossover earns an IIHS Top
Safety Pick and a five-star rating from
nitsa Trax starts at 21 grand with steel
wheels and all major options including
all-wheel drive and sunroof and the
retail price ventures into Buick
territory at 28 3 the small Trax has its
charm as long as buyers understand that
direct competitors offer bigger value
